label.string: The following early warning signs to be observed and acted upon as required

Add New Wound Assessment and Dressing Plan
Type of devices used to manage continence
Impaired skin integrity related to bowel or bladder incontinence
Complications related to indwelling urinary catheter

field.name: bag_below_level
field.string: Bag is below level of bladder

label.string: Patient/caregiver should always wash their hands before and after any procedure
Maintain fluids and high fibre diet to prevent constipation
Drinking at least 2 litres of fluid a day helps maintain the catheter to drain
Do not kink or clamp the catheter tubing
Always attach the catheter to the drainage bag or catheter valve
Keep a closed system of drainage and empty the drainage bag regularly
Carers should wash their hands and wear non-sterile gloves when emptying or changing the drainage bag
Complications related to dependence on tube feeding for nutritional support and hydration
Risk for aspiration, other complications related to tube feeding
Nutritional status changes related to ineffective calorie intake via tube feed
Will remain free of side effects or complications related to tube feeding
Will maintain adequate nutritional and hydration status as evidence by weight stable, no signs and symptoms of malnutrition or dehydration
Will not develop aspiration pneumonia or other complication related to tube feeding
Initiate feeding of 100 ml of Milk supplement and flush with 50 ml water
Presence of Gastric residual volume checked
Internal NGT Tube Length (cm) ( from nostril mark down to xiphoid process)
External NGT Tube Length Check (cm) (from nostril mark to tip of NGT opening)
Perform tube placement checking before and after feeding
Wash hands thoroughly before touching the Ng feeding tube, food, medication
Check the Placement of feeding tube before and after feeding, gastric content aspiration and check residual volume (amount, consistency)
Raise the head of bed 30° (semi fowler position) during feeding
Inform home care when feeding tube falls out or cannot confirm that the end of the tube is in the stomach and when there is difficulty in feeding
Reemphasize education on Enterl feeding, complications, care and management
Drain site will remain free from infection
Drainage system will remain patent with vacuum intact
Drain tube will be removed if less than 30mls drainage in last 24 hours
Drain remains insitu and drainage done as per doctor's order

Actions to take if leaking or tube becomes dislodged
Taking analgesia regularly or as required
Measuring and recording drainage as required
Report increase of temperature, change in color and amount of drainage
Discharge education post removal of draintube

label.string: Choose an outfit that will not affect the stoma and the collection bag
Eating a regular well balanced diet
Drink reqularly or take fluid at least 1.5 - 2 liters a day
Observe for stomal complications and report such as skin irritation or ulcers surrounding stoma, high or nil output, abdominal pain, nausea and vomiting.
Nutritional deficit related to poor oral intake
Nausea and/or vomiting related to medication/treatment
Constipation related to medication /immobility /decrease food or fluid intake
Psychosocial issues related to terminal prognosis
Will maintain adequate level of comfort as evidenced by no signs & symptoms of unrelieved pain or distress
Verbalizing relief of pain with ordered medications
Will function at optimal level within limitations imposed by disease process
Verbalizing satisfaction with level of comfort
Will demonstrate adjustment to end of life situation by verbally expressing feelings about death with family or social worker
Expressing through words or actions understanding of what is happening (ie. dying process)

Ensure that there is sufficient pain medication to last till next visit
Advice activity or movement 1 hour after taking pain medication
Advise to increase fluids as tolerated
Advice to take stool softeners for constipation
Take anti emetics 30 minutes before taking food

Will be/remain free from complications, bleeding, injury related to use of anticoagulation drugs
INR will be within therapeutic level
There will be no medication error related to taking of inappropriate warfarin dose
Patient will be compliant with taking warfarin dose

To report missed dose or delayed dosing
Check with home care staff before commencing new unprescribed drug
To observe for any bleeding from orifices
Correct technique in performing subcutaneous enoxaparin injection
Rotate injection sites and manage bruising

Patient taking appropriate diet and 30 mins after insulin injection is given
Check feet daily for any cracks in skin or lesion and wear appropriate footwear
Encourages activities and exercise as tolerated
Local irritation, inflammation or infection related to venipuncture / parenteral site
No Complication Of Pulmonary Micro Embolism

No parenteral site infection as evidence by site free from local irritation redness or inflammation

To inform home care when parenteral site accidentally removed and present to hospital if required
Apply warm compress to injection site
Fast relief from inflammation and allowing patient to breathe easier

label.string: What safe sleep surface is available
Advise to refrain putting stuffed animals, pillowe, quilts, blankets, positioners and other loose bedding or bumpers in the baby's sleep environment
Advise that sleep environment should be placed away from any item that could burn, cut, become wrapped around your baby
Advise not to share a sleep surface with a sibling, adult or pet
Advise on proper position of the baby when sleeping
Advise to refrain from smoking inside the home
Advise to change clothes before holding the baby after smoking outside the home
Advise that supervision is needed when baby is on tummy time while awake
Risk for dry or bloody nose, tiredness, and morning headaches
Presence of chest pain due to excessive coughing
Applies safe use of equipment and/or procedure practice
Never smoke, and don't let others light up near you
Risk for falls related to impaired mobility
Pressure ulcer/Altered skin integrity related to impaired mobility
Complications related to urinary / bowel incontinence
Free from injury related to falls
Free from skin redness, blisters or discoloration
Skin will be clean and dry with appropriate and prompt incontinence care
Skin clean, dry odor free and dressed appropriately
Any Changes in skin status, appearance, color
Ensure that patient hygiene is maintained at all times
Turn or change patient position regularly at least 2 hours, Perform range of motion exercises daily
Apply moisturiser to skin daily to prevent dryness
Inform Home Care Nurse if noted a skin discoloration, cracks, blisters, peel or break
Development of new pressure ulcer noted since last visit
Risk for Infection related to episiotomy/post-operative wound secondary to improper
Alteration in comfort, pain related to episiotomy/post-operative wound
Risk for fluid volume deficit related to vaginal bleeding secondary to post-partum complica
Risk for Maternal injury related to tissue oedema and hypoxia secondary to post partum
Will be able to demonstrate proper perineal care and post-operative wound care througho
Will maintain adequate level of comfort as evidenced by pain score below 4 throughout the
Vital signs remain stable with moderate amount of lochia within the next 7 days
Free of signs of cerebral ischemia within the next 7 days.
Advised on well-balanced nutrition, fluids and continue Vitamins and FolicAcid as supplement
Advised on ambulation to prevent constipation
Report to emergency department for sudden profuse blood loss, faintness, dizziness orpalpitation
Report to emergency department for headache accompanied by visual disturbances, nausea and vomiting
Report to emergency department for unilateral calf pain, redness or swelling, shortness of breath and chestpain
Advise to take prescribed analgesia for pain
Advise to palpate fundus and able to demonstrate how to massage uterus for soft, boggy uterus
Advise to empty bladder and be aware of need to empty frequently
Encourage to splint abdomen with pillow when coughing, moving or feeding
Observe for increased bleeding on post-operative dressing
Advise refrain form tub bath until dressings, sutures and staples removed
Advise to use good body mechanics and avoiding the Valsalva when lifting
Advise on frequent breastfeeding to help prevent engorgement
Advise on massaging breast gently and manually express milk to soften the areola before breastfeeding to facilitate infant latch
Advise application of warm compresses, shower or breast soak before breast feeding
Advise on care, support and breastfeeding technique for women with painful and damaged nipple and inverted nipple
Advise on lochia and perineum comfort measure
Advise on normal patterns of emotional changes in the postnatal period
Impaired skin integrity surrounding stoma related to reaction to product/chemicals
Skin integrity around stoma will be maintained
Patient/caregiver will demonstrate behaviours/techniques to promote healing/prevent skin breakdown
Coping with presence of tracheostomy tube and stoma
Change trache ties every other day and as needed
Use 2 finger technique to determine tightness and comfort of the patient
Observe for stomal complications and report such as skin irritation or ulcers surrounding stoma
Demonstrate safe use of equipment and/or procedure practice during suctioning
Checklist prior to administration of vaccine
Allergic or hypersensitivity to chicken, eggs

div.h5: Possible mild side effects include: These reactions usually disappear 1 - 2 days without treatment

field.string: Soreness, redness, and swelling at the injection site

div.h5: Severe allergic reaction, you need to bring the patient to a nearest hospital emergency department immediately
